column4: How can I use gksudo something to edit files on a server with a graphical application on my computer?
you need to open the connectio to the remote machine with ssh -X ... - (capital X)
I thought that required X on the server (which would be unusual)
it would require the actual program (for instance gedit), not an X server
as Ronnie just said, but don't use graphical programs with sudo
Ronnie: Thanks, I think I'll copy the file so I own it, edit with a graphical application then copy it back
easy enough done - use scp for the copying
trism: ANY good editor will let you edit over sftp (etc) - the issue is you do so as yourself, not as root, so you cannot edit root's files except with copying or changing permissions
from experience I prefer changing the ownership on the remote machine, but in such a case I would simply use a non GUI editor
I wouldn't change permissions/ownership on the original though - copy it, do your work, then copy it back
of course - I assumed as much :) , but still: is the task so big that you don't want to use nano or joe or vi(m) ?
cool, I'll read the man page
dig is the standard dns tool under linux - so that time will be well spent :)
ok, I'll double-check I've modified the right one...
